articles.headline: Within the Fed, Worries of Deflation
articles.snippet: A Fed member warned that the agency’s current policies put the United States economy at risk of  “Japanese-style” deflation.
articles.abstract: A Fed member warned that the agency’s current policies put the United States economy at risk of  “Japanese-style” deflation.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  A subtle but significant shift appears to be occurring within the Federal Reserve over the course of monetary policy as the economic recovery is weakening.

articles.headline: Citigroup Pays $75 Million to Settle Subprime Claims
articles.snippet: Besides the bank, two executives were singled out for not disclosing information about mortgage investments.
articles.abstract: Besides the bank, two executives were singled out for not disclosing information about mortgage investments.
articles.lead_paragraph: Citigroup agreed on Thursday to pay $75 million to settle federal claims that it failed to disclose vast holdings of subprime mortgage investments that were deteriorating during the financial crisis and ultimately crippled the bank.
articles.byline: By Eric Dash and Louise Story

articles.headline: In Basel, Eternal Work In Progress
articles.snippet: The Basel committee that was supposed to toughen banking regulations seems caught in a battle to do so.
articles.abstract: The Basel committee that was supposed to toughen banking regulations seems caught in a battle to do so.

articles.headline: S.E.C. Charges Brothers With $550 Million Fraud
articles.snippet: The two Dallas billionaires, large donors to conservative causes, were charged with an extensive securities fraud.
articles.abstract: The two Dallas billionaires, large donors to conservative causes, were charged with an extensive securities fraud.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Samuel and Charles Wyly, the billionaire brothers from Dallas who are large donors to philanthropies and to conservative causes, were charged Thursday with conducting an extensive securities fraud that the Securities and Exchange Commission said reaped $550 million in undisclosed gains.

articles.headline: Economists Expect Slower Growth in Second Half
articles.snippet: Economists are tempering their outlook ahead of a report on Friday on the nation’s output in the second quarter.
articles.abstract: Economists are tempering their outlook ahead of a report on Friday on the nation’s output in the second quarter.
articles.lead_paragraph: Two steps forward, one step back.

articles.headline: Gulf of Mexico Has Long Been Dumping Site
articles.snippet: For decades, the oil industry, farming and lax oversight have contributed to a dead zone in the gulf.
articles.abstract: For decades, the oil industry, farming and lax oversight have contributed to a dead zone in the gulf.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOUMA, La. — Loulan Pitre Sr. was born on the Gulf Coast in 1921, the son of an oysterman. Nearly all his life, he worked on the water, abiding by the widely shared faith that the resources of the Gulf of Mexico were limitless.

articles.headline: Rich I.P.O. Brings Controversy to SKS Microfinance
articles.snippet: The founder and early investors in the microlender will reap millions from the share deal, but it was unclear how donors would benefit.
articles.abstract: The founder and early investors in the microlender will reap millions from the share deal, but it was unclear how donors would benefit.
articles.lead_paragraph: An Indian company with rich American backers is about to raise up to $350 million in a stock offering closely watched by philanthropists around the world, showing that big profits can be made from small helping-hand loans to poor cowherds and basket weavers.
articles.byline: By Stephanie Strom and Vikas Bajaj

articles.headline: Taliban Exploit Openings in Neglected Province
articles.snippet: Deprived of jobs and government services, people in Baghlan Province are turning to the Taliban for speedy justice and work.
articles.abstract: Deprived of jobs and government services, people in Baghlan Province are turning to the Taliban for speedy justice and work.
articles.lead_paragraph: PUL-I-KUMRI, Afghanistan  Almost unnoticed, this strategic northern province is slipping away from government control.

articles.headline: Added to the Recall List: Millions of Frozen Mice
articles.snippet: Salmonella outbreaks that sickened more than 400 in the U.S. and Britain have been traced to mice sold as food for exotic pets.
articles.abstract: Salmonella outbreaks that sickened more than 400 in the U.S. and Britain have been traced to mice sold as food for exotic pets.
articles.lead_paragraph: Take mice from freezer. Thaw (but not in the microwave, please). Feed to pet snakes.

articles.headline: President to Promote Auto Bailout as a Success
articles.snippet: The White House has decided to argue more forcefully that investing in the auto industry helped keep workers employed and laid the groundwork for a rebound.
articles.abstract: The White House has decided to argue more forcefully that investing in the auto industry helped keep workers employed and laid the groundwork for a rebound.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When President Obama steps into a General Motors plant on Friday morning — as the majority shareholder surveying the government’s investment in a company the White House called “moribund” just 18 months ago — he will be doing more than just examining the first models of the plug-in hybrid Volt that began rolling off the production line this week.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger and Jackie Calmes

articles.headline: With Recovery Slowing, the Jobs Outlook Dims
articles.snippet: With growth at an annual rate of 2.4 percent in the second quarter and the stimulus fading, an analyst says the rest of the year will feel like a recession.
articles.abstract: With growth at an annual rate of 2.4 percent in the second quarter and the stimulus fading, an analyst says the rest of the year will feel like a recession.
articles.lead_paragraph: There is no more disputing it: the economic recovery in the United States has indeed slowed.

articles.headline: Taking Calls From Veterans on the Brink
articles.snippet: Critics call it a Band-Aid, but supporters say a suicide hot line is a gateway into government services.
articles.abstract: Critics call it a Band-Aid, but supporters say a suicide hot line is a gateway into government services.
articles.lead_paragraph: CANANDAIGUA, N.Y.  Melanie Poorman swiveled in her chair and punched a button on the phone. The caller, an Iraq war veteran in his 30s, had recently broken up with his girlfriend and was watching a movie, “Body of War,” that was triggering bad memories. He started to cry.
